text: It's dark, and so it takes us a minute to realize we're MOVING UP STONE SPIRALING STAIRS, up up up in what we now is a medieval cathedral.  And as we continue MOVING UP something TRICKLES DOWN INTO FRAME - BLOOD.  Running thin then thicker, as we CONTINUE TO MOVE UP the stairs and fi A BODY, sprawled awkwardly across the stones, arms and le akimbo, not so much Christ-like as victim-like.  In one h the Body holds a GUN he never had a chance to use.  In th other - A DARK SHAPE, we can't quite tell what it is. FOOTSTEPS sound from above and - THE KILLER walks into fr silenced pistol dangling at his side.  We don't know him, it's going to be a while before we see him again, but mar his face because we'll see him again.  The Killer now pic up the dark shape in the Body's hand, and we see it's - A BRIEFCASE.  The Killer cuffs the Briefcase to his wrist a turns to - TWO MEN standing behind him: subordinates.  Th Killer shows them the Briefcase.
God loves me. THE BODY suddenly twitches -- this guy is not quite dead. The Killer raises his silenced pistol.
(to his victim)
But I don't think he's too fond of you...
A PHONE RINGS, replacing the sound of the silenced gun sh we expected to hear. Rain-slicked cobblestones gleam in a twinkling of streetlight.

location: A PHONE BOOTH AT THE END OF THE STREET

text: The source of the ringing.  We start to PUSH SLOWLY IN on phone booth, and as we do we hear the VOICE of an UGLY AMERICAN.
What is this?
A SOCCER MATCH is in progress on a TV which sits above th bar in this smokey, dim dive.

This is not football... And now we're PULLING BACK DOWN THE LENGTH OF THE BAR.  W see THREE MEN sitting seperately at the bar, paying no attention to each other.  One of these men watches the ga with real interest.  The Ugly American talks on from off screen.
(continuing)
...Football is three hundred pound guys, they run way too fucking fast, they got helmets made of kevlar they use to spear the quarterback into the next life.
The phone is still ringing, louder now, and we're MOVING TOWARDS it while looking THROUGH AN UNSEEN PAIR OF EYES, even as we drink this in we're back in -

AT THE END OF THE BAR - LARRY, the Ugly American.  He's g an obvious attitude, all of it bad.  But there's somethin about the guy -- he's not all bluster, and he has the loo a seasoned tough guy who knows how to get rough and tumbl He's big, and yeah he's got a gut, but the rest of him lo solid.
(talking to the air)

You wanna know what football is?  It's hitting the other guy dirty and then spitting in his face when he's down. Football is all things American, and American is A-Number-One the absolute fucking best there is.  That's what football is... (he points to the TV)

...And that's not football. The one man at the bar who's been watching the gam turns slowly and gives Larry a long look.  This is VINCENT: Fre hard boiled and solid.  Charming when he wants to be, whi isn't all that often.  He gives Larry a long look and the speaks -
(to Larry in perfect English)

Football -- American football -- is a game for faggots. A BEAT.  The other two men at the bar, who seem like toug customers themselves, pretend not to watch too closely, b they're interested: what's Larry going to say?  For a mom it seems as if he's pissed, but then suddenly a smile bre out on his face and he laughs heartily at Vincent's remar Vincent joins in, as do the others.  In particular - THE BARTENDER looks relieved -- he's tough enough to toss a b drunk, but these guys are in a different league.  The Bartender laughs with the others, happy to have avoided a confrontation as we go back to -
We're almost ON TOP OF the phone booth, the phone is stil ringing as a HAND reaches INTO FRAME and snatches the pho from its cradle.
(a touch Irish accent)

Yes? ANOTHER ANGLE - And we see a woman named DEIRDRE on the phone: striking, dark-haired, Irish.  She carries herself with the same professional edge as the men inside the bar Deirdre listens for a moment to the voice on the other en and before she speaks she sense something - A SILHOUETTE stands in the shadows of the bar, watching Deirdre.  She gives this silhouette a measure glance before speaking, h hand creeping ever so slightly towards her coat.
Can I help you? The silhouette steps into a POOL OF LIGHT.  This is SAM. Tough, lean, enigmatic.  Somebody you might trust, but wh you'd never cross.  Sam returns her look before he speaks
No... Sam moves towards the bar, and Deirdre returns to her pho conversation.
I'm here... (a beat, responding to a question)
No, it was nothing.

Sam enters and by now the men inside have all come togeth at the bar, talking casually, recognizing they're somehow here for a reason.  With Larry and Vincent we see - GREGO man from Eastern Europe.  His accent is hard to pin down, but he most definitely has one.  Gregor has the air of an spook, and that's exactly what he is.  Lastly we see SWED blonde, muscular, and somehow blank in the face.  No, he' not stupid -- he's a sociopath.  Now - Sam looks at the group, which grows quiet as he enters.  Finally, Sam spea
Sorry I'm late...
(a challenge)
What makes you think we're here to meet you?
(meeting Vincent's gaze)
Who else would you be? Vincent turns towards the others, including them in an expansive gesture.
Perhaps the police?

I know cops -- and you're no cop. Vincent smiles at Sam's answer, satisfied, and makes room Sam to join them.  Vincent takes a pack of cigarettes, sh them so that one sticks out, and offers it to Sam.
Cigarette?
No thanks. Vincent looks a little disappointed at this as we go -

THE PAY PHONE makes a sharp noise as it's cracked back in the cradle.  Deirdre stands at the phone booth, lost in thought.  Then, without warning - Deirdre spins around, pulling TWO GUNS from inside her coat.  The move is fast, performed with the grace of a professional killer, as Der scans the horizon, but nobody seems to be watching.  Deir pockets her guns and steps into the shadows of the street the better to watch - THE BAR - And as Deirdre watches the bar we watch her. PULLING BACK from Deirdre, UP INTO THE AIR and then MOVIN

LOOKING THROUGH A WINDOW, donw onto the street below.  Ba visible we can see Deirdre.  And staring at Deirdre - THE WATCHER.  Somebody we're going to see periodically throug the movie.  Right now he's only a SILHOUETTE with a well- defined PAIR OF HANDS.  And in those hands - A KNIFE.  As Watcher watches he slowly cleans his nail with the knife, methodically, perfectly.  And he watches.  First Deirdre, then turning his attention to THE BAR.  He's especially interested in the bar.
The BARTENDER is wiping out a last glass.  When this is finished he looks up at -

Where our five guys have relocated.  Now the Bartender an Vincent exchange a look, and then the Bartender takes out set of keys and tosses them - THROUGH THE AIR and they SM into Vincent's hand.  The Bartender and Vincent speak in rapid-fire French, and then the Bartender is gone.  Sam t to Vincent.
He trusts you to lock up?
Let's just say he knows who I am. Vincent takes out his pack of cigarettes and offer them around the table -- again, nobody takes on.  Vincent seem really disappointed by this.
Anybody wanna tell me what we're waiting for?
(lighting his cigarette)
The question isn't what we're waiting for... it's who.
And who the fuck is that?
Whoever hired us.

I got this gig through a contractor. And he most definitely didn't know who was doing the hiring, only that they were paying a lot of money... There's a kind of general look around the table -- a nod grunt of acknowledgement, indicating that all of these me were hired the same way.
(continuing his thought)
So none of us knows who's paying the freight, this is just some anonymous job. For all we know, we're working for different people.
Now that is an interesting proposition.
How so?
Because if there's more than one party involved, if we really are working for different people, then perhaps some of us are on different sides. (with great meaning)
Your orders might be different from mine.
What're you talking about, man?  I don't understand.
(quietly, but loud enough to be heard)
What a surprise...
I got a surprise for you, blondie...
(sharply, as if he's used to giving orders)
Why don't both of you shut up?
(to Gregor at the same time)
Fuck you!

Knock it off! There is a BEAT.  Gregor, Swede and Larry look at Sam, wh glares them all down.  Lastly, Sam turns and looks at Vincent.  The two men nod at one another, acknowledging a kind of mutual respect.
The point remains: we could be working for different people.  There's a chance for one of us... (looks around the table)
Maybe more than one of us -- has been paid to cross the others.  I don't know about you guys, but I like to know who I'm working for.  It can help prevent a great deal of... (finding the right word)
...unpleasantness.
(patting the gun inside his cheap suit)

Anybody tries to unpleasant me I'll put two between his eyes -- one to do the job and the other to make sure it takes. From OFF SCREEN we hear a new sound: LAUGHTER.  ANOTHER A Deirdre has entered the bar, and she's amused by this las exchange.
It's good to see you've all got such faith in our little undertaking.
Who the fuck are you?
(staring at Larry)
The name is Deirdre, and I'm running this show.
Who are you?  IRA?
(with a brittle laugh)

Not likely.  Once, yeah, I was -- but there wasn't an inch of profit in it, and I'm a cash oriented girl, if you take my meaning.  I'm a hired gun, same as the rest of you, and that's all any of us needs to know about the other. Deirdre hands out several thick envelopes.  Larry and Swe open theirs and stare at the wads of Franc Notes stuffed inside.  Even Gregor cracks his envelope and peaks at his money.  But neither Vincent nor Sam takes a look.
From here on in you want something you pay cash for it: no credit cards, no bank accounts are in place: ten percent up front, the rest when the job is done. (a quick beat, then she looks at Gregor)
You.  What do you do and what should we call you?
These days they they call me Gregor -- and I'm a tech.  I do electronic work, surveillance, computer runs. Deirdre turns to Sam.
Sam.  I'm a weapons guy.
You were a soldier, were you?
Once. Deirdre gives Sam a look -- and he returns it.  Finally, Deirdre turns to Larry.
I drive -- and my name is Larry.  Larry from the States.
(she turns to Vincent)
And who are you?
I'm Vincent.  And I coordinate.
(sharply)
Coordinate what?

Things.  This is my country, you know. The two men exchange another look.  A pecking order is developing among the group: Vincent and Sam are both natu leaders, and now they're feeling one another out.
(to Vincent)
Coordinate all you want, but make sure whatever you do gets cleared through me. (Vincent doesn't respond for a moment)
Are we in sync on this, Vincent?
Of course. Deirdre waits a BEAT, letting Vincent know what she isn't more intimidated by him than he is by her.  Finally, she turns to Swede.
They call me Swede.
Who's they?
Everybody.
And what is it you do?
Me? (with a smile)
I kill.

A PAPER TARGET, in the shape of a human being, dances in place as it is riddles with GUNSHOTS, each shot hitting t target in the belly, each shot fired by - Larry, whose be shooting a sleek automatic pistol from which he's just discharged an entire clip.  The gun is empty, Larry turns Sam, who stands next in line.
(looking at the target)
You shoot alright.
Gets the job done.
All in the stomach, though.  Your man might live.
Not for long.
Long enough to shoot back.
Is that right?
It's been known to happen.
(a challenge)

Why don't you go do better, then... Without a word, Sam pops a new clip into the gun and SHOO THE LIGHTS out of several other human targets, hitting ea target in a different place.  One he clips between the ey the next in the heart, one in the groin, and then the las target - He SPLITS DOWN THE MIDDLE, firing shot after sho from the head to the groin until the target is sheared in half.  Larry is impressed in spite of himself.
Yeah, well...  My way works too.
My way is better.

text: Gregor has set up a table loaded with computers and electronic whizmos.  Right now Gregor is holding a particularly high-tech type CELL PHONE in his hands, look at it almost lovingly.
Is it alright? ANOTHER ANGLE - Deirdre sits nearby, looking at the cell phone.
It's quite satifactory.
Good, because it cost enough.  There's cheaper phones by far than that one, man: you better fucking use it.
(almost caressing the phone)

I intend to.  This phone is wired like no other: it's got an encryption chip and instant sat-a-link recognition, it can talk to any computer in any language and make it understand.  With my custom hardware and this phone I can trace the target's cell phone signature and follow him anywhere he goes...
You sure about this?
I'd stake my reputation.
But would you stake your life, that's the question...

In this business, your life and your reputation are more often than not one and the same. From off screen we hear MUNCHING.  It's - Larry inhaling sandwich.  A malicious look comes over Swede's face, who' cleaning a pistol and sitting near Larry.
You should watch what you eat.
Who the fuck died and appointed you food czar?
I'm just worried about your health, Larry.  You could stand to shed a few pounds.
(sensitive about his weight)
And you could stand to get a little smarter, ain't that right you dumb blonde fuck?
(sensitive about the dumb blonde thing)

Who you calling dumb, dickless? Both men eyeball one another, and then suddenly Larry rea for his piece, and as soon as he does this Swede does the same thing, but before they can do anything - DEIRDRE'S G swings INTO FRAME, smashing Swede in the face and droppin him to the floor.  Larry's mouth drops open in surprise, it's too late: Deirdre kicks him in the stomach and then rabbit punches him in the back of the neck, driving him t the ground.
(standing above them)

Next one of you fuckers plays this game I'm going to do for you myself.  I won't say it again: we don't have time for this shit!  There's a clock running on this job, gentlemen, and I mean to be on schedule. A TENSE MOMENT as Deirdre stares down at these tough guys letting them know who's in charge.  A SOUND from OFF SCRE interrupts this moment: a DOOR opening, as we see - Vince who stands in the door, wearing his coat and hat. He's been out somewhere, and he looks first at the squabb men, and then at - Deirdre.  She gives Vincent a little n a silent command that makes Vincent turn to Sam.
Let's go for a ride. Vincent and Sam start off, moving towards the door, while and larry slowly pick themselves up off the ground.
Where to?
To see a man about a thing.
I can do that.

A DESOLATE URBAN LANDSCAPE - Sam and Vincent walking away from the warehouse, which is housed in what looks to be t toughest neighborhood in the city, filled with CHEAP CONC PUBLIC HOUSING and INDUSTRIAL BUILDINGS. THE SETTING SUN throws a red glow on the street, giving t raw concrete buildings a blood-colored tint, as Sam and Vincent approach a FIAT, a car neither too old nor too ne Before they can reach the car, the two men are intercepte FOUR TOUGHS, young guys in their early twenties.  The LEA of the Toughs apporaches Vincent.
(subtitled French)
Who gave you permission to park here?
(to Vincent)
What's he saying?
Pretty much what you'd expect.
(with a sigh)
That's what I thought.
(in French)
There's a charge for parking on our block. The other Toughs add lib a few tough guy remarks (in Fren of course).
(to Sam)
He says this is their block.
As in, they own it?
Something like that...
And I suppose he's saying that we oughta give them something for using it, huh?
I didn't know that you spoke French.

I don't.  But the language he's speaking is universal. ANGLE ON THE LEADER - Who's smirking at Vincent and Sam. Sam's words make a great deal of sense: the Leader is speaking the universal language of "give me some money or I'll kick your ass."
I guess we oughta give them something... CUT BACK TO: Vincent and Sam.

If you think we should. Vincent backfists the Leader in the nose -- hitting him s hard that the Leader skitters back on unsteady feet and t sits down on his ass.  This blow hurt, but the real damag to the Leader's pride.  Now - One of the Toughs rushes at Sam, only to have Sam perform what looks like a jujitsu t which savagely jerks the Tough off his feet and flattens
(as if it were an accident)
Oh man, I am sorry about that... (he sticks his hand out)

Let me give you a hand. Sam reaches down as if to help the Tough, who ignores the hand and totters to his feet.  As soon as he's up he turn and runs away, followed by the other Toughs.  Now only th leader is left behind.  He looks for a second at Vincent Sam, and then turns and runs after his friends.  Vincent calls after him in French, but whatever he says isn't translated.  Vincent turns to unlock the car.
What'd you say to him?
I asked if we could give him anything else. By now the two men are in the car, which starts up and dr off, as it does we -
That was a nice move you did on our young friend.  Judo?
Jujitsu.
Same thing, isn't it?
Not at all.  Similar, but not the same.
What's the difference?
One's a lot more painful than the other. Vincent laughs, and Sam looks out the window at the city Paris as we MOVE THROUGH to the outside world of -

A SERIES OF QUICK CUTS of the car driving through Paris a night.  We don't see familiar sights like the Eiffel Towe the Arc de Triomph, but instead - We travel through the L BANK, down a series of Mazy Alleys which twist and turn, filled with bistros, bars and falafel joints.  NEON SIGNS line the streets for as far as the eye can see.  Near the of this trip we hear the SOUND OF A MATCH FLARING, follow by -
Could I get one of those?
Vincent is driving and smoking a cigarette.  He tosses hi pack to Sam, but he seems a little surprised at Sam's request.
Help yourself. (quick beat)
Since when do you smoke?
(lighting up)
I have, I don't know, maybe a cigarette a week.
A cigarette?  As in one? (exasperated, almost to himself)
One cigarette a week, who smokes like that?
I do.
Christ, I smoke a pack-and-a-half a day, and I tell myself I could be worse. (takes a satisfying drag)
It's just so damned pleasurable.
(blowing a smoke ring with great skill)
It has it's moments. (stubs out cigarette)
Course, you get cancer and die, that's the down side.
(with a sigh)
There is that. Vincent stamps his cigarette out, looking vaguely unhappy that Sam has spoiled his smoke.
So, Vincent: why bring me along for the ride?  Job like this calls for a warm body, somebody who can stand around and look threatening.  A tough guy.
Like Larry or Swede.
Exactly.  Why not bring them?
Let's just say I thought the conversational possibilities were limited.  Of course, I might have brought Gregor, but he didn't seem like the right candidate -- for this.
Watch that one, he's an ex-spook for sure, maybe Stasi, maybe KGB.  He's smart, Gregor is.
So is the woman.
Deirdre?  Smart, yeah, and seriously goddamned dangerous.
I wonder if she truly left the IRA.
I've wondered that myself.  None of this answers my question, though... (suddenly direct)
Why bring me?
I wanted to see who you were.
Who am I? Vincent, driving all the while, gives Sam a sideways glan before speaking.
You were once some kind of special forces.  Airborne Ranger, maybe a Navy SEAL.  After that you rode shotgun for the CIA in some place like El Salvador or Afghanistan, a real mercenary. (beat)
Only now -- now you're like the rest of us, it's a very competitive market since the end of the cold war.  There's a lot of hired guns out here, and not nearly enough work to go around.

That's right: there's not hardly enough work these days, nothing that pays the big money, anyhow.  Then along comes this job, paying so much goddamned money I couldn't afford not to take it.  Somebody's paying through the nose for this.
They certainly are.  Whatever it is we're going to steal, it must be quite something.
Whatever it is it must be goddamned priceless. And on that thought we -

The Fiat pulls up to the curb and Vincent and Sam get out Vincent leads Sam around a corner and they come to - AN EXQUISITE PARK, a small, perfectly manicured place -- kind of mini-Luxembourg Gardens in the middle of nowhere. When Sam sees the park, he draws an involuntary breath.
Lovely, isn't it?

They'd have to keep something like this under lock and key in New York, and it would still get fucked up. The two men enter the park, which is, indeed, open to the public.  Inside, sitting on a bench in the back, almost invisible from the street, we see - FRANCOIS, a stubble-f tough with a stained shirt and bad teeth.  Vincent and Sa draw near.  This next conversation between Francois and Vincent is in FRENCH WITH ENGLISH SUBTITLES.
That's good right where you are, Vincent. Vincent signals for Sam to stop.  Both Vincent and Sam ar still several feet away from Francois.
Do you have it?
Not so fast. (nods slightly to Sam)
Who's that?
He's company.
(as if he recognizes Sam)
Bad company...
What do you mean?

He's a cop, Vincent, he's French and he's a cop and you better shoot him in the fucking head right now! Sam hasn't said a word -- he doesn't seem to understand what's been said, but he has noted the urgency with which Francois spoke.  Now - We HOLD FOR A BEAT.  Neither Vince nor Francois pulls out a piece to shoot Sam.  Instead the wait to see if Sam will respond in any way to what Franco said.  The conversation now switches to ENGLISH, which (i turns out) Francois speaks fairly well.
(to Vincent)
What's going on?
I just wanted to see something.
(that edge creeping into his voice)
See what? Vincent isn't going to answer, but the overbearing Franco chimes in.
He wanted to see how you reacted when I said that you were a cop.
(he can't believe this)
You told him I was a cop?
He asked me to say it.
(looking at Vincent, truly pissed)
He asked you to?
I needed to know.
You need to know a lot of shit, Vincent.
(to Vincent, in subtitled French)

Are you ready? Francois's French words give Sam pause -- he's wondering what's being said, as - Vincent moves towards Francois, leaving Sam several steps away.  The conversation is agai SUBTITLED FRENCH.
(taking out an envelope)
Here's yours.
There's been a slight problem.
(immediately tensing)

What's that? Francois gives the slightest of nods, indicating that Vin should look towards a place perhaps thirty yards away - A COPSE OF TREES, where we see a SNIPER pointed a telesco rifle at Vincent.
(still in subtitled French)

If you say a word in English, Vincent, my friend with the high powered sporting rifle will shoot you in the throat. Sorry to screw you over like this, but the information you want might get me killed if I give it to you, and that's a price I'm not willing to pay.
(in French)
I take it you still want the money...
(in English, with a grin)

Of course. SAM'S POV: Looking at Vincent and Francois. The men are talking, and from here we can't really hear t speak.  All Sam can see is an earnest Vincent listening t Francois talk, almost as if Francois is giving Vincent instructions.  Now - Vincent reaches into his pocket, reaching for the envelope of cash he's carrying.  As he h the money to Francois, Vincent uses his free hand to pull his gun while - Sam already has his gun out -- somehow he figured out what was going on -- and now Francois looks o stunned disbelief as - Sam fires a single shot, hitting Francois in the shoulder driving him away from - Vincent, who now squeezes off sev rapid fire shots at the sniper, while - Francois, bleedin but still very much alive, now has his piece free just as The Sniper, his gun firing wildly into the air, falls to ground, shot dead by Vincent, and now - Francois is drawi bead on Vincent when - Sam hits Francois with a fusillade bullets in the chest and now - A SINGLE SPENT BULLED CASI flies through the air in SLOW MOTION and lands on the gro spinning around until it comes to a halt and - A HEAVY SILENCE FALLS, as the last echo of the last gunshot final dies.  Vincent and Sam look at one another, see that they still alive, and then look back at - The two men they've shot.  Francois isn't quite dead.  Blood bubbles from his lips as Vincent leans over him.  Again, they speak in
Where's my information?
(with a grim smile, pointing to his head)
In here...

Then you better find it in your heart to tell me, Francois, because while your death is inevitable, it still isn't decided how painful it's going to be. A LONG ANGLE - Vincent whispers in Francois's ear, whose blanches as he realizes Vincent means to hurt him.  Franc whispers something back and then - BANG.  Vincent shoots Francois in the head, killing him instantly.  Then Vincen bends down and retrieves the envelope of money which Fran had tucked inside his shirt.  As Vincent does this, Sam c up from behind.
Now would be a good time to get the fuck out of here.
The two men drive in silence for a moment.  Vincent light cigarette and offers one to Sam, who refuses.  Finally, S speaks.
You know, what you pulled back there, that was bullshit.
I needed to see if you were a cop. (defensively)

I'm a popular man with the police, Sam, and whenever they try to catch me they always do it with an inside guy -- some man on some job who seems more trustworthy than all the others put together.  And that's the guy you have to watch out for. (beat)
I hate cops...
(insulted that Vincent would even consider it)
Well I ain't a cop. A BEAT, the two men driving in silence.
How did you know?
Know what?
That there was a gun pointed at me.
I saw you look off when Francois nodded his head.  I figured he wasn't pointing out a particularly rare shrub, and the rest was easy.
But how did you know I would have the presence of mind to pull my weapon when I did?
(as if it's obvious)
Because that's what I would have done...

Vincent's Fiat is parked at the curb in front of this apartment house.  Vincent and Sam exit the car and move towards the house -- a silence hanging between them.  Rig before they go into the house, Vincent takes out the enve full of cash that was supposed to have been for Francois. thinks for a moment and then hands the whole envelope to

You saved my life back there in the park. I know this doesn't begin to make it right between us... Vincent's voice trails off -- he doesn't know what to say Sam takes the money out of the envelope -- half he keeps himself, the other he gives to Vincent.
What I did back in the park I did because we're working together -- we're on the same team. (holding up the money)
This is business -- this is work.  We did it together, we share the spoils, even split. Sam opens the door to the house, but Vincent has one last thing to say to him.
I owe you a heavy debt. Sam almost smiles cynically at this: debts of honor don't seem to be something he believes in.
Whatever you say. They enter the house and the door closes behind them.  A second later we hear -
What'd you do with the money?
Vincent and Sam sit with Deirdre in a room, alone.  They' told her about the park, and she seems a little pissed ab all of this.
We kept it...
(a little annoyed)
Is that right?
Hazard pay...
(with an exhalation of disgust)
The two of you were supposed to go to a simple meet and come back with a simple piece of information, and instead you went to fucking war...
We weren't real thrilled about it either... Deirdre shakes her head in disgust and rises.  We FOLLOW
Where Larry, Swede and Gregor are waiting.  They look up expectantly at Deirdre, who crosses through the room with stopping -- she's really pissed about this turn of events
So what's the deal?
(barely stopping, very snappish)
The deal?  The deal is we leave for Nice at first light. And she exits, leaving these three men behind along with and Vincent, who have entered from the other room.  larry looks at the two of them.
What'd you guys do?

A CAR sits, cloaked in shadows.  Inside sits our friend, WATCHER.  Once again we see the Watcher's knife -- once a he manicures his nails with it, almost delicately, as he watches the House.  It's dark -- a single light glows beh a window on the third floor.  Sam's room.

Sam has pushed all the furniture aside to make enough roo do a martial arts form.  Right now he's frozen, one leg extended in a kick, balancing on the other leg.  Now - A KNOCK at his door -- seconds later, it opens.  Deirdre st there, watching as Sam holds his position for a BEAT more and then retracts his leg.
I feel as if I've wandered onto the set of Enter The Dragon.  Could you teach me to do that?
I didn't think to see you again tonight. You were pretty pissed.
I still am.
Is that right?

That's right. Deirdre spings at Sam, throwing martial arts combinations him: punch followed by kick, elbow strike followed by pal thrust.  Sam parries her blows as she drives him across t floor until he's got his back to the wall.  Their movemen are controlled, but powerful, and there's something almos flirtatious about the whole thing.  Now - Deirdre throws one last punch which Sam ducks.  He slips behind her and suddenly they square off in earnest.  The previous martial arts stuff was a kind of choreographed exercise, but now - They spar for real -- they never hit another, but they come awfully close, hands and feet whiz through the air, throwing rapid-fire combinations and techniques.
